text: Iliya Pavlov Naydenov () (August 6, 1960 – March 7, 2003) was a Bulgarian businessman. A banker, financier, philanthropist and mason, he was the leader and founder of the Multigroup organization and G-13. Pavlov was ranked the eighth richest man in Central and Eastern Europe by the Polish magazine Wprost in 2002. He was said to be worth $US1.5 billion.http://najbogatsieuropejczycy.wprost.pl/ide,13/edycja-2002.html He was married to Darina Pavlova, who inherited his fortune after his murder. ==Death== Pavlov was shot outside his office with a single bullet to the heart by a sniper and died instantly.http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=20098 The day before his death, he had testified in the trial of the accused murderers of Andrey Lukanov, Bulgaria's first prime minister after the fall of communism who died in 1996. Pavlov had claimed that he had no conflict with Lukanov. No one has been charged in Pavlov's murder and while several possible theories have been put forth the motive is unknown. A previous attempt on Pavlov's life was made in 1997 when a bomb destroyed his car. He was not in it at the time.http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=112713 In 2010 Pavlov's sister, Slavka Naydenova, and her 8-year-old son were murdered in Dale City, Virginia. A Russian-American woman who was the wife of Naydenova's ex-husband pleaded guilty to the murders. The motive was jealousy.http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=137307 ==Sports career== Pavlov was a former Bulgarian wrestling champion who graduated from the National Sports Academy in Sofia. ==See also== *List of Bulgarians *Bulgarian mafia ==References== Category:1960 births Category:2003 deaths Category:Bulgarian businesspeople Category:People from Sofia City Province Category:Murdered businesspeople Category:Assassinated Bulgarian people Category:Deaths by firearm in Bulgaria Category:Murdered Bulgarian mobsters Category:People murdered in Bulgaria Category:Bulgarian mobsters Category:Sportspeople from Sofia Category:Unsolved murders in Bulgaria Category:20th-century businesspeople
